newsitem.title: USA: Citrix says Microsoft talks are continuing.
newsitem.headline: Citrix says Microsoft talks are continuing.

text.p: Citrix Systems Inc executives on Tuesday said the company was still in discussions about licensing its technology to Microsoft Corp.

"We are in the middle of negotiations," Edward Iacobucci, Citrix's chairman, told investors at the Hambrecht & Quist Technology Conference in San Francisco. "It would be unwise for us to disclose details of our negotiations."

Citrix, based in Coral Springs, Florida, writes software that allows inexpensive computer terminals connected to corporate networks to use most of the software that runs on Windows-based personal computers. Microsoft owns about six percent of Citrix's stock.
In February, Microsoft told Citrix executives that it planned to put the capabilities of Citrix's WinFrame program into the Microsoft Windows NT program.
Afterwards Citrix's stock plunged amid concerns that Microsoft would wipe out much of Citrix's sales.
Since then, Citrix and Microsoft have been in negotiations. Citrix executives have been trying to license the company's technology without hurting their own sales.
Iacobucci said the companies would "have a deal," but that Citrix was working to get the most favorable terms.
He said the company generates plenty of revenue from other products. "We will have a viable business," Iacobucci said.
